title: Tourism up almost 30 percent in Tunisia
description:
(1 Aug 2017) LEADIN:
Tunisia's tourism sector is recovering two years after deadly attacks meant many people decided not to holiday in the country.
There's been a 29.3 percent rise in tourists in the first six months of the year compared to same period in 2016.
STORYLINE:
Spectators crowd the streets in Sousse for the opening of the Aoussou carnival.
It's a happy occasion that's in the stark contrast to the atmosphere here two years ago.
Back then, the Tunisian resort was reeling from an attack by an extremist gunman which left 38 tourists dead and sent the tourism sector into freefall.
But the industry is now showing clear signs of recovery.
At the Kantaoui Bay Hotel, where the attack took place, measures are in place to prevent a repeat of the tragedy.
"We take the tourist identities and we check the information before they enter. We verify people in cars and their identities and we keep all the information about them. We check the cars using mirrors and with metal detectors. We try to secure the hotel and the tourists," says Ahmed Hleli, Security chief for Kantaoui Bay Hotel.
And at the Thalassa Hotel, guests are showing no signs of concern as the relax in the swimming pools.
Swiss tourist Florence believes attacks are just as likely to happen in Europe as they are here.
"Terrorist acts are everywhere in the world, either in Paris or here. I am still coming to Tunisia," she says.
The Tunisian Federation of Hotels (FTH) has released figures showing a 29.3 percent rise in tourists in the first six months of the year compared to the same period in 2016.
Algerian visitors are up 61.2 percent to more than 760,000 and Libyan tourists have risen 30.6 percent to almost 620,000.
Tunisia's traditional markets are also recovering: French tourists have risen by 43.2 percent to more than 200,000.
Russian tourist Maria says there is "no fear" in coming to Tunisia.
The FTH predicts the number of European tourists will grow 30 percent to 2 million visitors.
That could be helped by a recent decision by the British government to relax its travel advice.
It is no longer cautioning against travelling to Tunisia, except for certain regions of the country.
"The travel ban and the removal of restrictions on visiting Tunisia is a sign of confidence in the security in Tunisia," says Afif Kchok Director of Tunisian Observatory of Tourism.
"This will improve tourism because Britain is a large market and also a strong sign to other European countries that Tunisia is safe."
